pageTitle: MS004: Pokémon 4Ever - Celebi: Voice of the Forest - The Pokémon Wiki
TableContextTimeStampAfterTable: {44745=Although Kids' WB! currently airs the film, it aired on CBS on May 21, 2007 (due to the fact that Paramount released the film), being the third Pokémon film to air on CBS (the first two being the next films Pokémon: Jirachi Wishmaker and Pokémon: Destiny Deoxys)., 43814=Pokémon 4Ever (Japanese: 劇場版ポケットモンスター セレビィ 時を越えた遭遇, Gekijōban Poketto Monsutā Serebii Toki o Koeta Deai, lit. "Pocket Monsters the Movie: Celebi: The Meeting that Traversed Time"; officially POCKET MONSTERS CELEBI A TIMELESS ENCOUNTER in Japan) is the fourth official Pokémon movie. It was the first one to be distributed by Miramax Films and fourth Pokémon film to be released in wide theaters outside of Japan in 2002. The original Japanese version was released in theaters on July 7, 2001, and the English adaptation saw limited theatrical release on October 11, 2002.}
textBeforeTable: CastEdit Celebi Tyranitar Piloswine Sneasel Jumpluff Croconaw PokémonEdit Vicious Towa Mr. White Dundee Diana CharacterEdit DebutsEdit The credits end with Tracey clearing Oak's room and finds Sam's drawing pad, containing a faded sketch of Pikachu and Celebi. The reason being that Sam was actually a young version of Professor Oak, whose first name is Samuel. Celebi prepares to bring Sam back in time. He has an emotional farewell with Ash and departs with Celebi. The movie ends with Ash and company talking to Professor Oak, who muses about the story and tells a confused Ash that he and Sam are going to be friends forever. With the destruction of the dragon shape, the Iron Masked Marauder falls into the lake. The other heroes rush to the lake's edge and find Ash and Sam with Celebi, who suddenly falls limp. Ash and Sam realize Celebi is dead and everyone weeps. However, the Voice of the Forest materializes in the sky and thousands of Celebi
textAfterTable: ReceptionEdit The film was a box-office bomb, it received poor reviews from critics and fans. On Rotten Tomatoes it has a "rotten" rating of 14% based on 37 reviews and at Metacritic it has a 25 out of 100 based on 16 reviews and stating: Generally unfavourable reviews. TriviaEdit This is the first movie not feature a legendary Pokémon that can speak human. This page uses content from Wikipedia. The original article was at Pokémon 4Ever. The list of authors can be seen in the page history. As with the Pokémon Wiki, the text of Wikipedia is available under the GNU Free Documentation License.
